III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iii)Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or otherwise
suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C AWOLed and Staff 1 allegedly
attempted to hit youth with a car and threatened to shoot them
with a gun.
Investigation On 4/30/24 I spoke to Complainant 1. No new information was
provided.
On 4/30/24, I spoke to DHHS Worker 1. Allegations and
scheduling were discussed.
On 4/30/24, I spoke to DHHS Worker 2. No new information was
provided.
On 4/30/24, I spoke to Administrator 1. Administrator 1 reported
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C went AWOL on 4/29/24.
Administrator 1 reported Staff 1 had followed the youth when they
went AWOL on 4/29/24 but did not come back with them. He
stated the youth came back on their own and did not file any
complaints or grievances. Administrator 1 reported he has not had
any areas of concern for Staff 1 in the past.
The following interviews were conducted at the facility with
DHHS Worker 1 on 4/30/24.
Youth A
Youth A reported he went AWOL with Youth B and Youth C on
4/29/24. Youth A reported they were offsite (unknown area) and
Staff 1 tried to run them over with his vehicle. Youth A reported
they (youth) were walking together, and Staff 1 was driving in his
2

jeep behind them. Youth A reported they were always walking in
front of the vehicle. Youth A reported Staff 1 said, “I’m gonna beat
you up and hit you with my car.” Youth A reported Staff 1 also told
them if they kept walking, Staff 1 was going to pull something out
of his glovebox. Youth A reported Staff 1 was referring to a gun.
Youth A was unable to provide why he thought this meant a gun.
After stating this, Youth A then reported Youth B saw the gun.
Youth A was asked how the gun was seen if they were walking in
front of the vehicle and he reported, “He just did.”
Youth B
Youth B reported he went AWOL with Youth A and Youth C on
4/29/24. Youth B reported they left the facility grounds and went
offsite. Youth B reported Staff 1 saw them and followed them in
his black jeep. Youth B reported Staff 1 didn’t say or do anything
that was inappropriate. Youth B then reported Youth C started to
pound his fists on Staff 1’s jeep and Staff 1 stated, “watch and see
what I pull out of this glove box.” Youth B reported Staff 1 was
referring to his gun. When asked how he knew this, he stated he
knew Staff 1 had a “black Glock 19.” Youth B reported they ran
from Staff 1. Youth B reported later, they came back to the facility,
went into the cottage, and ate something. Youth B denied seeing
the gun.
Youth C
Youth C reported he went AWOL with Youth A and Youth B on
4/29/24. Youth C reported Staff 1 saw him and attempted to help
them, but they would not listen and left the facility. Youth C
reported Staff 1 followed them in his jeep. Youth C reported they
started calling Staff 1 “bitch.” When they did this, Staff 1 yelled
back, “You’re gonna see what’s in my front pouch.” Youth C
reported Staff 1 was referring to a gun. When asked why he
thought this, Youth C reported his dad has a gun and he has
watched videos where guns are to be placed in the vehicle. Youth
C reported at one point the youth were walking and Staff 1 sped
up and tried to hit them. Youth C reported Staff 1 came about six
feet behind them. Youth C reported Staff 1 didn’t say anything
else because it was raining that night, and his windows were up.
Staff 1
Staff 1 reported Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were running
around at the facility on 4/29/24 in the evening. Once he saw them
leave the facility grounds, he went into his jeep and followed them.
Staff 1 reported he followed them through neighborhoods and
Youth B had cussed at him and Youth A was stating he was going
to damage Staff 1’s car. Staff 1 reported he responded by telling
3

Youth A that he was following a “10-year-old and letting him lead.”
Staff 1 was attempting to show Youth A he didn’t need to follow
Youth B. Staff 1 reported the only other conversation he was
attempting to have with the youth, was asking them to come back
to the facility. Youth A continued to use profanity as he followed.
Staff 1 reported they stopped at a house and because it was dark
outside and him following three children in the dark, may look
suspicious, he went back to the facility. Staff 1 reported he was
always about 10-15 feet away from the youth. Staff 1 reported he
was always behind them. Staff 1 reported the youth were never
close enough to touch his car, except Youth A who came near his
car. Staff 1 reported Youth A did not punch his car or hit it to
damage it. Staff 1 reported when he stopped following them, he
turned around in a grassy field and went to the facility. Staff 1
reported he does have a Glock 22 caliber but does not bring this
to work and has not discussed having one with the youth.
Administrator 1 reported they came back at 9:50pm.
Documents Reviewed:
• I reviewed the Incident Report dated 4/29/24. The incident
report states they went AWOL at 8:05pm; no return time
noted.
• Staff 1 personnel file: There is no discipline in Staff 1’s
file. All clearances and training are up to date.
• I reviewed their Behavior Management Policy which
indicated threats of physical harm is a prohibited form of
intervention.
Analysis There is no evidence to validate the allegations. All three-youth
had different accounts of the situation and all three youths’
accounts were inconsistent.
Consultation:
Consultation was provided for all AWOL situations. Staff 1
followed three youth at nighttime, in his own personal jeep. Staff 1
had followed them by himself. In the future, the agency may want
staff to use company vehicles and utilize more than one staff
when searching and following AWOL youth. This will provide
safety for youth and staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
